From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Mon May 19 16:56:56 2008
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Mon May 19 16:57:04 2008
Subject: [Harbour] hb_ReleaseCPU for UNIX need to be fixed ASAP
In-Reply-To: <9257026e0805191243h3eb58f42h79be07aaa55ceaa1@mail.gmail.com>
References: <9257026e0805191243h3eb58f42h79be07aaa55ceaa1@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20080519205656.GA9266@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>

On Mon, 19 May 2008, Lorenzo Fiorini wrote:
> After the changing from:
> #elif defined(HB_OS_UNIX)
>    {
>       static const struct timespec nanosecs = { 0, 1000000 };
>       nanosleep( &nanosecs, NULL );
>    }
> 
> to:
> #elif defined(HB_OS_UNIX)
>    {
>       struct timeval tv;
>       tv.tv_sec = 0;
>       tv.tv_usec = 1000;
>       select( 0, NULL, NULL, NULL, &tv );
>    }
> the "black screen" problem under Centos 5.1 went away.
> Is it the right fix?

If it helps then it's a workaround for problem with Linux kernel
(or glibc nonosleep() implementation) in Centos 5.1 which should
be fixed in this distribution.

> Should I commit it?

You can safely commit it. Using select() in such way is the most
portable method of process freezing for delay less then second in
POSIX systems. So simply change:
   #elif defined(HB_OS_DARWIN)
to:
   #elif defined(HB_OS_UNIX)
and remove current HB_OS_UNIX section which uses nanosleep() code.

best regards,
Przemek
From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Mon May 19 17:01:54 2008
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)

    * changed --without gpl to --without gpllib

  * harbour/source/compiler/complex.c

      for better error reporting in wrong .prg code

Przemek

Subject: RE: [Harbour] Foreign libs


>> Then I try add this three lib but from hbmake I receive error C: 
>> \HARBOUR\BIN\bin\harbour.cfg cannot be created. FERROR

>I didn't want to raise this, but, is there any objection
>to actually _remove_ hbmake altogether? Seems like it
>raises more questions than does good, and I cannot see
>many people wanting to maintain this app.. After all
>it's installed in the /bin folder, and it will make an
>an immediate bad impression on Harbour for anyone starting
>with it.

Any opinions?

IMO a make system is important
My suggestion is made something siple as sostititive for hbmake so 

/ PDH Project  Definition Harbour - File created by hbmake Version 2.0
Date: 21.10.08 Time: 15:32:27
WARNINGLEVEL =  0
COMPILE_FLAG = -DEURO 
GUI = YES
OBJ = objpath
[myproject.exe] = myprg1.prg ,myprg2.prg, my sample prg3.prg, mytest.ch
mysamplec.c ,express.res, lang.lib ,vm.lib, rtl.lib, pcrepos.lib,
rdd.lib, macro.lib, pp.lib, dbfntx.lib, bmdbfcdx.lib, dbfcdx.lib,
dbffpt.lib  ,hbsix.lib ,common.lib,gtwvt.lib, codepage.lib ,ct.lib
,tip.lib ,rddads.lib ,ace32.lib, c:\mypath\mylib.lib ,wvtgui.lib

IMO no other variable is necessary in hbmake
This project definition pdh is Simple to create, simple to post on ng


hbmk -pc myproject.pdh  // for project compiling
hbmk -pp myproject.pdh  // wizard for create  new project
hbmk -f  myproject.pdh  // for complete rebuild project
hbmk -p show pdh createted for compile 
list of phd files will start if you exec hbmk without parameter
old parameter remain for compatibility

What do you think?

I am not able starting this working but is something start (and is a
prg) I can test and implement

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Tue May 20 06:59:31 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Tue May 20 07:00:43 2008
Subject: [Harbour] ERROR BLD_B32
In-Reply-To: <AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC1F@SRV02.deltain.net>
References: <AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC1F@SRV02.deltain.net>
Message-ID: <E045980A-A58A-425E-AF38-5599A194E9F8@syenar.hu>

> My Harbour binary is installed in \harbour\bin\b32

Please use 'make_b32.bat install' (with default HB_*_INSTALL
envarrs) before running bld_b32.bat in tests.

I may add some tweaks to make it possible to override
install dir for bld_b32.bat, too (or better yet, I'll
remove all HB_*_INSTALL presets from there), but only
after the release. You can tweak those files locally
until then (and if 'install' is not an option), they
are just a few lines.

Non-GNU make files were not designed to support
parallel VC/B32 builds, that's one reason they
can be simpler (that's we don't deal with /bin/b32
directly, it's a _temp_ dir!). If you want this
functionality, check the GNU make system which works
similar to this.

Brgds,
Viktor

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Tue May 20 07:40:02 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?iso-8859-2?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)

2008-05-20 13:30 UTC+0100 Viktor Szakats (harbour.01 syenar hu)
   + contrib/hbvpdf
   + contrib/hbvpdf/common.mak
   + contrib/hbvpdf/hbvpdf.prg
   + contrib/hbvpdf/hbvpdf.ch
   + contrib/hbvpdf/make_gcc.sh
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/fonts.dat
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/files
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/files/color.tif
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/files/test.txt
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/files/color.jpg
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/pdf_demo.prg
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/tstpdf.prg
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/bld_b32.bat
   + contrib/hbvpdf/tests/bld_vc.bat
   + contrib/hbvpdf/hbvpdft.prg
   + contrib/hbvpdf/make_b32.bat
   + contrib/hbvpdf/make_vc.bat
   + contrib/hbvpdf/Makefile
     + Added Viktor K's pure Clipper pdf lib.
     + Added Pritpal's OOP version.
     + Added make files, reorged dir layout, named 
       files to avoid collision.
     + Added minor #define tweak to compile as-is.
     * Renamed pdf.ch to hbvpdf.ch for above reasons, 
       if this hurts anybody, I will correct it.
     ! Fixed unused vars and a few other things.
     ; TOFIX: - ShellExecute(), GetDeskTopWindow() 
                dependencies commented out.
              - fonts.dat dependency is a PITA, so 
                this file should be moved inside 
                the .prg somehow.
              - There are some hard-wired non porable 
                things like acrobat executable path.

   * contrib/Makefile
   * contrib/make_b32_all.bat
   * contrib/make_gcc_all.sh
   * contrib/make_vc_all.bat
     + hbvpdf added to make systems.
--
Brgds,
Viktor

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Tue May 20 09:18:19 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Tue May 20 09:19:32 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Release harbour documentation as pdf
In-Reply-To: <AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC22@SRV02.deltain.net>
References: <AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC1E@SRV02.deltain.net>
	<4478A260-68DE-4922-8590-757D74FDF9C8@syenar.hu>
	<AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC22@SRV02.deltain.net>
Message-ID: <03930463-10CB-4767-A2A5-367A102D1870@syenar.hu>

> You suggest implement hbdoc or starting from it for a new project?

I suggest to modify current hbdoc to use one
of our working pdf engines (either hbvpdf or
hbhpdf).

[
See 2008-04-24 21:23 UTC+0100 entry, how to
turn on PDF creation in HBDOC.

set HARBOURFLAGS=-DHBDOC_PDF
set LDFLAGS=-Lhbvpdf.lib

(above example for B32 and hbvpdf. untested.)
]

Brgds,
Viktor

-----Original Message-----
From: harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org [mailto:harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org] On Behalf Of Szak?ts Viktor
Sent: Tuesday, May 20, 2008 3:18 PM
To: Harbour Project Main Developer List.
Subject: Re: [Harbour] Release harbour documentation as pdf

> You suggest implement hbdoc or starting from it for a new project?

I suggest to modify current hbdoc to use one
of our working pdf engines (either hbvpdf or
hbhpdf).

[
See 2008-04-24 21:23 UTC+0100 entry, how to
turn on PDF creation in HBDOC.

set HARBOURFLAGS=-DHBDOC_PDF
set LDFLAGS=-Lhbvpdf.lib

(above example for B32 and hbvpdf. untested.)
]

Brgds,
Viktor

From: harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org [mailto:harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org] On Behalf Of Szak?ts Viktor
Sent: Tuesday, May 20, 2008 3:18 PM
To: Harbour Project Main Developer List.
Subject: Re: [Harbour] Release harbour documentation as pdf

> You suggest implement hbdoc or starting from it for a new project?

I suggest to modify current hbdoc to use one
of our working pdf engines (either hbvpdf or
hbhpdf).

[
See 2008-04-24 21:23 UTC+0100 entry, how to
turn on PDF creation in HBDOC.

set HARBOURFLAGS=-DHBDOC_PDF
set LDFLAGS=-Lhbvpdf.lib

(above example for B32 and hbvpdf. untested.)
]

Brgds,
Viktor

Massimo,

Just use /make_b32.bat, it will take care of it.

If you want a separate one, you'll have to create
your own, maybe someone else can help you. I've mentioned
it a few times, try taking a look into /contrib/examples/dbu/
for an example. I cannot help any more than that.

About your mail on the warnings in genpdf1.prg:
Yes, this is unused, broken, disabled code! It needs
a rewrite.

Brgds,
Viktor

From: harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org [mailto:harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org] On Behalf Of Massimo Belgrano
Sent: Tuesday, May 20, 2008 3:27 PM
To: Harbour Project Main Developer List.
Subject: RE: [Harbour] Release harbour documentation as pdf

How compile only hbdoc?

-----Original Message-----
From: harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org [mailto:harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org] On Behalf Of Szak?ts Viktor
Sent: Tuesday, May 20, 2008 3:18 PM
To: Harbour Project Main Developer List.
Subject: Re: [Harbour] Release harbour documentation as pdf

> You suggest implement hbdoc or starting from it for a new project?

I suggest to modify current hbdoc to use one
of our working pdf engines (either hbvpdf or
hbhpdf).

[
See 2008-04-24 21:23 UTC+0100 entry, how to
turn on PDF creation in HBDOC.

set HARBOURFLAGS=-DHBDOC_PDF
set LDFLAGS=-Lhbvpdf.lib

(above example for B32 and hbvpdf. untested.)
]

Brgds,
Viktor

	<AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC2C@SRV02.deltain.net>
Message-ID: <E56C3DD6-EBBA-409A-B1F0-4D4500524E0C@syenar.hu>

The unresolved variables belong to the old - removed -
PDF lib, so it's normal they are unresolved. The actual
task would be to replace these with hbvpdf (or hbhpdf)
calls. It's definitely LDFLAGS for your case, since LDLIBS
is not used by our non-GNU make system.

Brgds,
Viktor

Message-ID: <AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC30@SRV02.deltain.net>

Wich kind of makefile is in Utils\hbdoc\makefile?
Will this structure be used as make_file instead old hbmake?

#
# $Id: Makefile 8377 2008-04-24 19:26:54Z vszakats $
#

ifeq ($(HB_MAIN),)
    HB_MAIN = std
endif

ROOT = ../../

PRG_SOURCES=\
	hbdoc.prg \
	genos2.prg \
	gentrf.prg \
	genng.prg \
	genhtm.prg \
	genchm.prg \
	genrtf.prg \
	genhpc.prg \
	genasc.prg \
	genpdf1.prg \
	teeasc.prg \
	html.prg \
	ng.prg \
	os2.prg \
	rtf.prg \
	troff.prg \
	fclass1.prg \
	ffile1.prg \
	ft_funcs.prg \

PRG_MAIN=hbdoc.prg

LIBS=\
	hbdebug \
	hbvm \
	hbrtl \
	hbrdd \
	hbrtl \
	hbvm \
	hbmacro \
	hbpp \
	hblang \
	hbcommon \

include $(TOP)$(ROOT)config/bin.cf


-----Original Message-----

hbmake was created with such goal, 9 years ago, you can
see where it stands now. I personally think the basic goal
of hbmake is wrong. In any case we'd need active _developers_
and a clear vision for such a tool (any tool). I personally
cannot contribute in either areas regarding hbmake. If
there are any takers _now_, good, otherwise I'd vote to
move hbmake to contrib/examples/.

As an aside, I myself have some make problems locally,
...still using rmake, which is choking on GCC, and
on large projects in general. So, I think it would be a
true-to-the-goal and useful idea to implement an rmake
compatible, but portable tool in Harbour. Notice the goal
is completely different from the current hbmake. This also
needs takers though, and there is the thing that several
make packages exist even on the OSS scene, so some may
consider it a duplicate effort.

Brgds,
Viktor

_______________________________________________
Harbour mailing list
Harbour@harbour-project.org
http://lists.harbour-project.org/mailman/listinfo/harbour

   * contrib/hbmysql/tests/bld_vc.bat

   * contrib/hbnf/tests/bld_vc.bat

   * contrib/hbvpdf/tests/bld_vc.bat

   * contrib/hbw32/tests/bld_vc.bat
   * contrib/hbw32ddr/tests/bld_b32.bat
   * contrib/hbw32ddr/tests/bld_vc.bat
   * contrib/hbzlib/tests/bld_b32.bat
   * contrib/hbzlib/tests/bld_vc.bat
   * contrib/rddado/tests/bld_b32.bat
   * contrib/rddado/tests/bld_vc.bat
   * contrib/rddads/tests/bld_b32.bat
   * contrib/rddads/tests/bld_vc.bat
     ! Fixed to honor HB_*_INSTALL envvar settings in 
       bld_*.bats for /tests

   * contrib/examples/hscript/dir.hs
   * contrib/examples/hscript/bld_b32.bat
   - contrib/examples/hscript/makehtm.bat
     * Cleanup.

   * contrib/rddads/rddads.h
   * contrib/rddads/adsfunc.c
   * contrib/rddads/ads1.c
   * contrib/rddads/adsmgmnt.c
     * Header cleanup, minor code opt.
     * ADS_REQUIRE_VERSION==8 is now equivalent to 
       ADS_LIB_VERSION=810. Brian suggested this is what 
       the majority of users need. See next however.
     * ADS_REQUIRE_VERSION compatibility handling 
       disabled to make usage and support more 
       straightforward. I'd suggest everyone to remove 
       any old ADS_REQUIRE_VERSION settings, if - and only 
       if - there is a need to force an older version, 
       ADS_LIB_VERSION=??? should be used, where ??? is 
       810 for ACE 8.11 (for example).
--
Brgds,
Viktor

Error: Unresolved external '_HB_FUN_PDFOPEN' referenced from C:\HARBOUR\OBJ\B32\GENPDF1.OBJ
Error: Unresolved external '_HB_FUN_PDFTEXT' referenced from C:\HARBOUR\OBJ\B32\GENPDF1.OBJ

-----Original Message-----
From: harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org [mailto:harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org] On Behalf Of Szak?ts Viktor
Sent: Tuesday, May 20, 2008 9:05 PM
To: Harbour Project Main Developer List.
Subject: Re: [Harbour] Release harbour documentation as pdf

The unresolved variables belong to the old - removed -
PDF lib, so it's normal they are unresolved. The actual
task would be to replace these with hbvpdf (or hbhpdf)
calls. It's definitely LDFLAGS for your case, since LDLIBS
is not used by our non-GNU make system.

Brgds,
Viktor

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Wed May 21 10:41:57 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?iso-8859-2?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Wed May 21 10:42:13 2008
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2008-05-21 16:30 UTC+0100 Viktor Szakats
 (harbour.01 syenar hu)
Message-ID: <01c8bb50$Blat.v2.6.2$d1b8e200$1b90f5af2bec@127.0.0.1>

2008-05-21 16:30 UTC+0100 Viktor Szakats (harbour.01 syenar hu)
   * make_b32.mak
   * make_vc.mak
   * make_vcce.mak
     + Added HBDOC_LIBS to specify external libs for HBDOC.
       Only for non-GNU B32/VC/VCCE builds! For non-GNU GCC 
       it's probably LDFLAGS, for GNU it's probably LDLIBS.
       NOTE: Use full path for the libs.
       Such dependency is anything by good though (the core 
       build depends on a contrib lib, the contrib lib depends 
       on the core build), so consider this a temporary solution.
       Moving HBDOC to the contrib area is one possibility, 
       dropping it is another one.
     ; There is quite a big mess regarding these envvars depending 
       on the type of make system, platform, compiler, etc, 
       that it's almost impossible to document or understand, so 
       maybe it'd be worth a review after the release, and sync 
       all these external flag and dir envvars.
       
   * utils/hbdoc/genpdf1.prg
     ! Fixed warnings in HBDOC_PDF guarded code.
--
Brgds,
Viktor

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Wed May 21 15:19:38 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Wed May 21 15:20:50 2008
Subject: [Harbour] PCRE 7.7 update
Message-ID: <0DD752CA-98E8-4A55-850B-8B8135A53ECE@syenar.hu>

Hi,

I have it pending, managed to solve the update
in a way that's less painful, there're a few
files static to Harbour, and there is a script
which renames/converts the PCRE sources to the
Harbour short filename format. This way there
is no need to manually edit any foreign sources.

My question is: Is it a reasonable concept, to
not manually patch the files to suppress warnings,
rather, either ignore them or use #pragmas to
achieve that? Even if it's not perfect, it can
be a good compromise for easier updates (that
is until someone submits these patches to the
PCRE project.)

There is now an easy way to add any of those
#pragmas in a file called _hbconf.h, which gets
injected between the PCRE source files and the
original PCRE config.h.

Brgds,
Viktor

Szak?ts Viktor wrote:

>      ; There is quite a big mess regarding these envvars depending 
>        on the type of make system, platform, compiler, etc, 
>        that it's almost impossible to document or understand, so 
>        maybe it'd be worth a review after the release, and sync 
>        all these external flag and dir envvars.

They are not environment variables, but how did we end up with lines 
like this? :

CFLAGS = -Ot2b1 -EHs-c- -FD -Gs -W3 -nologo -D__WINDOWS__ -DWIN32 
-D__WIN32__ -D_CRT_SECURE_NO_DEPRECATE

This is taken from LetoDB just as an example, but three different 
manifest constants to say we are targeting Windows!

Regards
Alex

From mbelgrano at deltain.it  Thu May 22 04:59:24 2008

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Thu May 22 05:38:10 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Thu May 22 05:39:20 2008
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2008-05-21 16:30 UTC+0100 Viktor Szakats
	(harbour.01 syenar hu)
In-Reply-To: <48351F7E.9090705@mweb.co.za>
References: <01c8bb50$Blat.v2.6.2$d1b8e200$1b90f5af2bec@127.0.0.1>
	<48351F7E.9090705@mweb.co.za>
Message-ID: <F62938C8-0BF4-4971-904D-663282267816@syenar.hu>

>
Hi Alex,

> Szak?ts Viktor wrote:
>
>>     ; There is quite a big mess regarding these envvars  
>> depending        on the type of make system, platform, compiler,  
>> etc,        that it's almost impossible to document or understand,  
>> so        maybe it'd be worth a review after the release, and  
>> sync        all these external flag and dir envvars.
>
> They are not environment variables, but how did we end up with lines  
> like this? :
>
> CFLAGS = -Ot2b1 -EHs-c- -FD -Gs -W3 -nologo -D__WINDOWS__ -DWIN32 - 
> D__WIN32__ -D_CRT_SECURE_NO_DEPRECATE

In most cases - given properly crafted C code - only one,
or none of these should suffice, at least in Harbour. I've
removed tons of such (pretty much all of them) from contribs
a while ago.

Generally in Harbour, if a C source uses Windows API, it
should #define HB_OS_WIN_32_USED before any #includes.
(this could be further enhanced by just #including
"windows.h" locally, in case Windows platform is detected
by the Harbour headers.).

Ideally a central header should do the Windows platform
detection, and define _one_ macro to signal that, so
source code can rely solely on this macro, and don't have
to deal with all the variations as above. IMO.

Brgds,
Viktor

From guy.roussin at teledetection.fr  Thu May 22 12:58:53 2008
From: guy.roussin at teledetection.fr (Guy Roussin)
Date: Thu May 22 12:59:08 2008
Subject: [Harbour] make_deb.sh
Message-ID: <4835A64D.9050608@teledetection.fr>

Hi,

I notice that HB_CONTRIBLIBS in make_deb.sh is not taken into
account by dpkg-buildpackage -b

As a workaround i add this line before dpkg-buildpackage -b :
export HB_CONTRIBLIBS

So even if the package libpq-dev is there, libhbpgsql.a is not
compiled.

I also suggest to add those lines in make_deb.sh :

if test_reqpkg libmysqlclient15-dev
then
      HB_CONTRIBLIBS="${HB_CONTRIBLIBS} hbmysql"
fi

Thank you,

-- 
Guy Roussin

From mbelgrano at deltain.it  Fri May 23 05:20:49 2008
From: mbelgrano at deltain.it (Massimo Belgrano)
Date: Fri May 23 05:20:56 2008
Subject: [Harbour] 2008-05-22 19:00 UTC+0800 Pritpal
	Bedi(pritpal@vouchcac.com)
In-Reply-To: <17417347.post@talk.nabble.com>
References: <17417347.post@talk.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC49@SRV02.deltain.net>

I confirm that dialog one in sample now works!
Thanks
Have you (or anybody) other sample gtwvg?
will wopen and WvtClass merged in same screen?
Can Help me working this demo?

Function Main()
   WVT_Core()
   WVT_Utils()
   Wvt_SetGui( .t. )
   Wvt_SetFont( 'Courier New', 18, 0, 0 )
   Wvt_SetMouseMove( .t. )
   Wvt_setCodePage( 255 )
   SetMode( 25, 80 )
   SetColor( 'W/R' )
   SetPos( 10,10 )

   ? 'This is Harbour GT Demo'

   MyOtherGT()

   Do while lastkey() <> 27 
   Enddo

   Return nil

Function MyOtherGT()
   Local oBrw
   Local hbpGT := Hb_WOpen( 20, 20, .... )

   SetColor( 'W+/B' )
   CLS
   @ 1,5 SAY 'HARBOUR New Window' COLOR 'N/W'

   Setkey( K_F11, {|| Hb_WClose( hbpGT ) } )  

   oBrw := TBrowseNew( 1,2,19,18, hbpGT )
   oBrw:Execute()

   Return nil
//-------------------------------------------------------------------//
// Wvt_SetFocus() must be a FUNCTION in your application
// needs to process messages sent through WM_SETFOCUS message
// received by the window.
//-------------------------------------------------------------------//
FUNCTION Wvt_SetFocus( hWnd )
RETURN nil

//-------------------------------------------------------------------//
// Wvt_KillFocus() must be a FUNCTION in your application
// needs to process messages sent through WM_KILLFOCUS message
// received by the window.
//-------------------------------------------------------------------//
FUNCTION Wvt_KillFocus( hWnd )
RETURN nil

Thanks. 
Actually initially I placed the class in WvtPaint.prg but them moved to
devowvg.prg just to draw a little focus on this issue. As per now it is too
heavy because ::aColumnsSep is being calculated each time a WM_PAINT message
is received for that region which is triggered with every movement in
Tbrowse.

::doConfigure() ? (I remember your posts) but have a strong point as it does
not interfere with compatibility issue. Przemek ?

Hi Pritpal,

I think the better way to do this is to override
:doConfigure() and do this calculation locally
after getting back control from the super :doConfigure().

If this is doable, this is what we should do instead
if implementing app specific code into the core
(even if done in a "hidden" way).

Brgds,
Viktor

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Fri May 23 11:21:10 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Fri May 23 11:22:34 2008

	<17426364.post@talk.nabble.com>

	<17427561.post@talk.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <A2A0C3CF-ED33-4678-899D-D5616B08D00D@syenar.hu>

>
Hi Pritpal,

> Done. And is fine for all practical purposes. The only concern is to  
> change
> my sources for Harbour and xHarbour. Anyway, I can do that, not a  
> big deal.

Thanks, great!

> Can all the GT calls in TBRowse be routed to a method with similar  
> name?
> That way I can override those methods too to suit MULTI-WINDOW GT  
> without
> touching the core.

You cannot route through function calls, but as Przemek suggested,
the internals of TBrowse can be rearranged in such a way, that
screen output gets isolated from all internal logic into
"presentation" methods (which would higher level stuff than a
simple "DispOut()"), and if this is done, you'll only have to
override these methods and use whatever display functions
that suit your needs to display the browse parts.

Brgds,
Viktor

From jarabal at ya.com  Fri May 23 12:52:13 2008
From: jarabal at ya.com (Javier)
Date: Fri May 23 12:52:31 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour ANSI C sprintf() for ANSI SQL.
Message-ID: <4836F63D.7000901@ya.com>

IMHO.-
I need to implement a sprintf () compatible ANSI C and ANSI SQL to generate HTML, mount SQL sentences of an effective way in
critical processes or simply mount messages of the application and debugging of a easy way.

Attach spd.c file, please check if it is Harbour compatible.
For my part is no objection to incorporate in the project if you consider it opportune.

----------------------------------
Tengo necesidad de implementar un sprintf() compatible ANSI C y ANSI SQL para poder generar HTML, montar sentencias SQL de una
forma efectiva en procesos cr?ticos o sencillamente, montar mensajes de la aplicaci?n y de depuraci?n de una forma m?s simple.

Adjunto el fichero spd.c, por favor, chequear si es Harbour compatible.
Por mi parte no hay ning?n inconveniente en que se incorpore al proyecto si lo consider?is oportuno.
----------------------------------

Procedure Test()
       Local i, n, k, nCount := 0, nMaxCount := 100000
       Local cRes, cSQL, dFecha1 := Date() - 1, dFecha2 := Date() + 1

       nCount := 17/13
       cRes := _SPD( "%%%-3.2f%%%n SQL DATE %s%n SQL %s SQL %d SQL %s%n", ;
                      nCount, @i, dFecha1, @n, TRUE, FALSE, nil, @k )
       ? cRes   // "%1.31% SQL DATE 2008-05-18 SQL TRUE SQL 0 SQL NULL"
       ? i, n, k	// 6 26 50

       cSQL := "SELECT * FROM Tabla WHERE Fecha >= '%s' AND Fecha < '%s'"
       nCount := Seconds()
       for i := 1 to nMaxCount
          cRes := _SPD( cSQL, dFecha1, dFecha2 )
       next
       ? _SPD( "%-3.2fs %s", Seconds() - nCount, cRes )
return

best regards
Xavi
-------------- next part --------------
/*******************************************************************************
* ANSI C sprintf() for ANSI SQL with DATE, DATETIME, LOGICAL, NIL, NUMERIC
* ------------------------------------------------------------------------
* cRes := _SPD( cFrm, ... )
* cFrm : %s for DATE = YYYY-MM-DD, DATETIME = YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS
*        %s for LOGICAL = TRUE | FALSE, %d for LOGICAL = 1 | 0
*        %s for NIL or HB_IT_NULL = NULL
*        %s is also for NUMERIC
* NOTE .-
* Accepts conversion inside if variable is passed by reference.
* Local xDate := Date(); _SPD('%s', @xDate) => xDate == '2008-05-19'
*
* TODO: Support in format % for $.
*
*******************************************************************************/
/*
 * Harbour Project source code:
 * _SPD() function
 *
 * Copyright 2008 Xavi <jarabal@gmail.com>
 *
 * This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
 * it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
 * the Free Software Foundation; either version 2, or (at your option)
 * any later version.
 *
 * This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
 * but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 * MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
 * GNU General Public License for more details.
 *
 * You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
 * along with this software; see the file COPYING.  If not, write to
 * the Free Software Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330,
 * Boston, MA 02111-1307 USA (or visit the web site http://www.gnu.org/).
 *
 * As a special exception, the Harbour Project gives permission for
 * additional uses of the text contained in its release of Harbour.
 *
 * The exception is that, if you link the Harbour libraries with other
 * files to produce an executable, this does not by itself cause the
 * resulting executable to be covered by the GNU General Public License.
 * Your use of that executable is in no way restricted on account of
 * linking the Harbour library code into it.
 *
 * This exception does not however invalidate any other reasons why
 * the executable file might be covered by the GNU General Public License.
 *
 * This exception applies only to the code released by the Harbour
 * Project under the name Harbour.  If you copy code from other
 * Harbour Project or Free Software Foundation releases into a copy of
 * Harbour, as the General Public License permits, the exception does
 * not apply to the code that you add in this way.  To avoid misleading
 * anyone as to the status of such modified files, you must delete
 * this exception notice from them.
 *
 * If you write modifications of your own for Harbour, it is your choice
 * whether to permit this exception to apply to your modifications.
 * If you do not wish that, delete this exception notice.
 *
 */

#include "hbapi.h"
#include "hbapiitm.h"
#include "hbapierr.h"
#include "hbdate.h"

#define DK_INCRES 1024
#define DK_INCBUF 512
#define DK_BLKBUF HB_MAX_DOUBLE_LENGTH   /* Expense of DK_INCBUF */

static ULONG SCItm( char *cBuffer, char *cParFrm, int iCOut, int IsIndW, int iIndWidth, int IsIndP, int iIndPrec, PHB_ITEM pItmPar )
{
   ULONG s = 0;

   if( IsIndW && IsIndP ){
      switch( iCOut ){
      case 'p':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, iIndWidth, iIndPrec, hb_itemGetPtr( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 's': case 'S':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, iIndWidth, iIndPrec, hb_itemGetCPtr( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 'e': case 'E': case 'f': case 'g': case 'G': case 'a': case 'A':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, iIndWidth, iIndPrec, hb_itemGetND( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 'c': case 'C': case 'd': case 'i': case 'o': case 'u': case 'x': case 'X':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, iIndWidth, iIndPrec, (HB_IS_LONG( pItmPar ) ? hb_itemGetNL( pItmPar ) : hb_itemGetNI( pItmPar )) );
      }
   }else if( IsIndW || IsIndP ){
      int iInd = (IsIndW ? iIndWidth : iIndPrec);

      switch( iCOut ){
      case 'p':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, iInd, hb_itemGetPtr( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 's': case 'S':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, iInd, hb_itemGetCPtr( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 'e': case 'E': case 'f': case 'g': case 'G': case 'a': case 'A':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, iInd, hb_itemGetND( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 'c': case 'C': case 'd': case 'i': case 'o': case 'u': case 'x': case 'X':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, iInd, (HB_IS_LONG( pItmPar ) ? hb_itemGetNL( pItmPar ) : hb_itemGetNI( pItmPar )) );
      }
   }else{
      switch( iCOut ){
      case 'p':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, hb_itemGetPtr( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 's': case 'S':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, hb_itemGetCPtr( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 'e': case 'E': case 'f': case 'g': case 'G': case 'a': case 'A':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, hb_itemGetND( pItmPar ) );
         break;
      case 'c': case 'C': case 'd': case 'i': case 'o': case 'u': case 'x': case 'X':
         s = sprintf( cBuffer, cParFrm, (HB_IS_LONG( pItmPar ) ? hb_itemGetNL( pItmPar ) : hb_itemGetNI( pItmPar )) );
      }
   }
   return s;
}

HB_FUNC( _SPD )
{
   char *cItmFrm;
   ULONG ulItmFrm;
   int argc = hb_pcount() - 1;
   PHB_ITEM pItmFrm = hb_param( 1, HB_IT_STRING );

   if( !pItmFrm || (cItmFrm = hb_itemGetCPtr( pItmFrm )) == NULL ){
      hb_errRT_BASE_SubstR( EG_ARG, 3012, NULL, "_SPD", 1, hb_paramError( 1 ) );
   }else if( !(ulItmFrm = hb_itemGetCLen( pItmFrm )) ){
      hb_retclen( "", 0 );
   }else if( !argc ){
      hb_retclen( cItmFrm, ulItmFrm );
   }else{
      PHB_ITEM pItmPar;
      char *cRes, *cBuffer, *cParFrm, *c;
      int p, iCOut, IsIndW, IsIndP, iIndWidth, iIndPrec, iErrorPar = 0;
      ULONG s, f, i, ulWidth, ulParPos = 0, ulResPos = 0, ulMaxBuf = DK_INCBUF, ulMaxRes = DK_INCRES;
      static char cToken[] = "scdiouxXaAeEfgGpnSC";

      cRes = (char *)hb_xgrab( ulMaxRes );
      cBuffer = (char *)hb_xgrab( ulMaxBuf );
      cParFrm = (char *)hb_xgrab( ulItmFrm + sizeof(char) );

      for( p = 0; p < argc; p++ ){

         c = cItmFrm + ulParPos;
         f = i = ulWidth = iCOut = IsIndW = IsIndP = 0;
         do{   /* Get Par Format */
            if( f && *c == '%' ){
               f = ulWidth = IsIndW = IsIndP = 0;
            }else if( f == 1 && !ulWidth && *c >= '0' && *c <= '9' ){
               ulWidth = atol( c );
            }else if( f && *c == '.' ){
               if( f++ == 2 ) iErrorPar = 1;
            }else if( f && *c == '*' ){
               if( f == 2 ){
                  if( IsIndP ){
                     f = 3; iErrorPar = 1;
                  }else{
                     IsIndP = 1;
                  }
               }else if( !IsIndW ){
                  ulWidth = IsIndW = 1;
               }else{
                  f = 3; iErrorPar = 1;
               }
            }else if( f && *c == '$' ){
               f = 3; iErrorPar = 1;   /* TO DO */
            }else if( f && strchr(cToken, *c) ){
               f = 3; iCOut = *c;
            }else if( *c == '%' ){
               f = 1;
            }
            cParFrm[i++] = *c++;
         }while( f < 3 && *c ); cParFrm[i] = '\0';
         if( iErrorPar ) break;

         if( IsIndW  ){ /* Get Par Indirectly Width Item */
            pItmPar = hb_param( p + 2, HB_IT_INTEGER );
            if( pItmPar ){
               if( (iIndWidth = hb_itemGetNI( pItmPar )) < 0 ){
                  ulWidth = -iIndWidth;
               }else{
                  ulWidth = iIndWidth;
               }
            }else{
               iErrorPar = 1; break;
            }
            p++;
         }

         if( IsIndP ){  /* Get Par Indirectly Precision Item */
            pItmPar = hb_param( p + 2, HB_IT_INTEGER );
            if( pItmPar ){
               iIndPrec = hb_itemGetNI( pItmPar );
            }else{
               iErrorPar = 1; break;
            }
            p++;
         }

         if( *c && p == argc - 1 ){ /* No more Par Items */
            do{ cParFrm[i++] = *c; }while( *c++ ); i--;
         }  /* i == strlen(cParFrm) */

         pItmPar = hb_param( p + 2, HB_IT_ANY );   /* Get Par Item */
         if( !pItmPar ){
            iErrorPar = 1; break;
         }

         if( !iCOut || iCOut == 'n' ){ /* Par Text Out */
            for( f = i, i = 0; i < f; i++ ){ /* Change %% with % */
               if( cParFrm[i] == '%' && cParFrm[i + 1] == '%' ){
                  memcpy( cParFrm + i, cParFrm + i + 1, f - i );
                  f--;
               }
            }  /* i == strlen(cParFrm) */
            if( iCOut ){
               for( f = 0; f < i; f++ ){  /* Erase %n */
                  if( cParFrm[f] == '%' && cParFrm[f + 1] == 'n' ){
                     memcpy( cParFrm + f, cParFrm + f + 2, i - f - 1 );
                     break;
                  }
               }  /* f == Index % of n */
               if( f < i ){
                  i -= 2;  /* i == strlen(cParFrm) */
                  hb_itemPutNL( pItmPar, ulResPos + f );
               }else{
                  iErrorPar = 1; break;
               }
            }
            if( (f = i + sizeof(char)) > ulMaxBuf ){
               ulMaxBuf += f + DK_INCBUF;
               cBuffer = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cBuffer, ulMaxBuf );
            }
            strcpy( cBuffer, cParFrm ); s = i;

         }else{   /* Par Item sprintf() Out */
#        ifdef HB_IT_NULL
            if( (HB_IS_NIL( pItmPar ) || HB_IS_NULL( pItmPar )) && iCOut == 's' ){
#        else
            if( HB_IS_NIL( pItmPar ) && iCOut == 's' ){
#        endif
               if( (f = i + HB_MAX(ulWidth, 5)) > ulMaxBuf ){
                  ulMaxBuf += f + DK_INCBUF;   /* size of "NULL" == 5 */
                  cBuffer = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cBuffer, ulMaxBuf );
               }
               hb_itemPutCL( pItmPar, "NULL", 4 );
               s = SCItm( cBuffer, cParFrm, iCOut, IsIndW, iIndWidth, IsIndP, iIndPrec, pItmPar );

            }else if( HB_IS_STRING( pItmPar ) && (iCOut == 's' || iCOut == 'S') ){
               f = hb_itemGetCLen( pItmPar );
               if( (f = i + HB_MAX(ulWidth, f)) > ulMaxBuf ){
                  ulMaxBuf += f + DK_INCBUF;
                  cBuffer = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cBuffer, ulMaxBuf );
               }
               s = SCItm( cBuffer, cParFrm, iCOut, IsIndW, iIndWidth, IsIndP, iIndPrec, pItmPar );

            }else if( HB_IS_DATE( pItmPar ) && iCOut == 's' ){
               char cDTBuf[ 19 ], cDTFrm[ 26 ];

#           ifdef __XHARBOUR__
               if( HB_IS_DATETIME( pItmPar ) ){
                  hb_datetimeFormat( hb_itemGetDTS( pItmPar, cDTBuf ), cDTFrm, "YYYY-MM-DD", "HH:MM:SS" );
               }else
#           endif
                  hb_dateFormat( hb_itemGetDS( pItmPar, cDTBuf ), cDTFrm, "YYYY-MM-DD" );

               if( (f = i + HB_MAX(ulWidth, 26)) > ulMaxBuf ){
                  ulMaxBuf += f + DK_INCBUF;
                  cBuffer = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cBuffer, ulMaxBuf );
               }
               hb_itemPutC( pItmPar, cDTFrm );
               s = SCItm( cBuffer, cParFrm, iCOut, IsIndW, iIndWidth, IsIndP, iIndPrec, pItmPar );

            }else if( HB_IS_LOGICAL( pItmPar ) ){
               if( (f = i + (iCOut == 's' ? HB_MAX(ulWidth, 6) : HB_MAX(ulWidth, DK_BLKBUF))) > ulMaxBuf ){
                  ulMaxBuf += f + DK_INCBUF;   /* size of "FALSE" == 6 */
                  cBuffer = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cBuffer, ulMaxBuf );
               }
               if( iCOut == 's' ){
                  hb_itemPutC( pItmPar, (hb_itemGetL( pItmPar ) ? "TRUE" : "FALSE") );
               }
               s = SCItm( cBuffer, cParFrm, iCOut, IsIndW, iIndWidth, IsIndP, iIndPrec, pItmPar );

            }else if( HB_IS_NIL( pItmPar ) && iCOut == 's' ){
               if( (f = i + HB_MAX(ulWidth, 5)) > ulMaxBuf ){
                  ulMaxBuf += f + DK_INCBUF;   /* size of "NULL" == 5 */
                  cBuffer = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cBuffer, ulMaxBuf );
               }
               hb_itemPutCL( pItmPar, "NULL", 4 );
               s = SCItm( cBuffer, cParFrm, iCOut, IsIndW, iIndWidth, IsIndP, iIndPrec, pItmPar );

            }else if( iCOut == 's' ){
               char *cTrimStr, *cStr = hb_itemStr( pItmPar, NULL, NULL );

               if( cStr ){
                  f = strlen( cStr ); cTrimStr = hb_strLTrim( cStr, &f );
                  if( (f = i + HB_MAX(ulWidth, f)) > ulMaxBuf ){
                     ulMaxBuf += f + DK_INCBUF;
                     cBuffer = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cBuffer, ulMaxBuf );
                  }
                  hb_itemPutCL( pItmPar, cTrimStr, f );
                  s = SCItm( cBuffer, cParFrm, iCOut, IsIndW, iIndWidth, IsIndP, iIndPrec, pItmPar );
                  hb_xfree( cStr );
               }else{
                  iErrorPar = p + 2; break;
               }

            }else if( HB_IS_NUMERIC( pItmPar ) || HB_IS_POINTER( pItmPar ) ){
               if( (f = i + HB_MAX(ulWidth, DK_BLKBUF)) > ulMaxBuf ){
                  ulMaxBuf += f + DK_INCBUF;
                  cBuffer = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cBuffer, ulMaxBuf );
               }
               s = SCItm( cBuffer, cParFrm, iCOut, IsIndW, iIndWidth, IsIndP, iIndPrec, pItmPar );

            }else{
               iErrorPar = p + 2; break;
            }
         }

         if( (f = s + ulResPos + sizeof(char)) > ulMaxRes ){
            ulMaxRes += f + DK_INCRES;
            cRes = (char *)hb_xrealloc( cRes, ulMaxRes );
         }
         strcpy( cRes + ulResPos, cBuffer ); ulResPos += s;

         if( (ulParPos = c - cItmFrm) >= ulItmFrm ){
            break;   /* No more Par Format */
         }
      }
      hb_xfree( cParFrm ); hb_xfree( cBuffer );
      if( iErrorPar ){
         hb_xfree( cRes );
         if( iErrorPar > 1 ){
            hb_errRT_BASE_SubstR( EG_ARG, 3012, NULL, "_SPD", 2, hb_paramError( 1 ), hb_paramError( iErrorPar ) );
         }else{
            hb_errRT_BASE_SubstR( EG_ARG, 3012, NULL, "_SPD", 1, hb_paramError( 1 ) );
         }
      }else{
         hb_retclen( cRes, ulResPos );
         hb_xfree( cRes );
      }
   }
}
/* END */

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Sat May 24 05:56:35 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Sat May 24 05:57:45 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Date/Time xHarbour compatible functions
In-Reply-To: <17444038.post@talk.nabble.com>
References: <17444038.post@talk.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <956483B2-D22D-4EF3-B34E-822B58051CDB@syenar.hu>

Hi Pritpal,

[ These are those xhb date/timestamp handling functions
if I'm not mistaken. ]

Not at this moment. These are yet to be discussed along
with the rest of the implementation details.

I believe though, that these could even be developed without
any special Harbour core support; using current API tools only
(hb_parptrGC()/hb_retptrGC()), even as part of the xhb
contrib. [ Except maybe those strange syntax extensions, in
case they cannot be PPed. ]

Brgds,
Viktor

From bedipritpal at hotmail.com  Sat May 24 10:38:36 2008
From: bedipritpal at hotmail.com (Pritpal Bedi)

Subject: [Harbour] Date/Time xHarbour compatible functions

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Sat May 24 11:35:11 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Sat May 24 11:36:21 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Date/Time xHarbour compatible functions
In-Reply-To: <17448495.post@talk.nabble.com>
References: <17444038.post@talk.nabble.com>
	<956483B2-D22D-4EF3-B34E-822B58051CDB@syenar.hu>
	<17448495.post@talk.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <96FE6D0E-6CFD-4782-806E-E910489D49CB@syenar.hu>

You allocate a structure which holds all the data
you want (date + time), and implement the various
conversions.

Look at any code using hb_parptrGC() (contrib/hbhpdf is t
he latest example), the idea is the same, only the content
of the structure and the related functions are different.

Brgds,
Viktor

From bedipritpal at hotmail.com  Sat May 24 11:52:56 2008

From niki at synel.co.il  Sun May 25 02:42:20 2008
From: niki at synel.co.il (Chen Kedem)
Date: Sun May 25 02:47:06 2008
Subject: [Harbour] SourceForge issues
Message-ID: <1A07FEDC778C3E4AA417F089511F859C0215F398B0@Mail-yoq.SYNEL-COMPANY.LTD>

File upload mechanism was changed in the past month. Upload via anonymous FTP is not supported
any more. See this link:
http://alexandria.wiki.sourceforge.net/File+Release+System+-+Offering+Files+for+Download

When we did a release, users uploaded the files to FT and one of the project admins took the files
and used them to create a release in the SF Download page. Now, it seems that each user can only
see that files that he/she was uploaded, so the admin can't see files contributed by other members.
I post a question on the SF community forum (which sucks by the way), and this is the reply I got:
http://sourceforge.net/community/forum/topic.php?id=2393


And now for something completely different. If you feel like, you can vote for Harbour in the
Sourceforge.net 2008 Community Choice Awards
http://sourceforge.net/community/cca08-badge?group_id=681

  Chen.

Hi Miguel,

Harbour has it's own solution for this problem,
so in case we will support this feature in an xhb-like
way, the xhb compatible (but namespace polluting)
functions will be put into xhb contrib lib, so you
can continue to use them, even in indexes.

Brgds,
Viktor

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Mon May 26 06:15:21 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?iso-8859-2?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Mon May 26 06:15:35 2008
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2008-05-26 12:13 UTC+0100 Viktor Szakats
 (harbour.01 syenar hu)
Message-ID: <01c8bf19$Blat.v2.6.2$67ace6b2$7484447892a@127.0.0.1>

2008-05-26 12:13 UTC+0100 Viktor Szakats (harbour.01 syenar hu)
   * include/hbapi.h
   * source/vm/extend.c
     + Added hb_retc_null() which is equivalent to 
       hb_retc( NULL ) and will return an empty string.
       I opted for this because hb_retc( NULL ) usage is not 
       compatible with CA-Cl*pper _retc(), so it might create 
       problems when writing C code intended for both Clipper 
       and Harbour.

   * contrib/hbclipsm/stack.c
   * contrib/hbclipsm/environ.c
   * contrib/hbclipsm/status.c
   * contrib/hbclipsm/gauge.c
     % Optimizations.
     ; TOFIX: GAUGE*() still leaks and doesn't seem to function.

   * contrib/rddads/adsmgmnt.c
     % Optimizations (using hb_arraySet*()).
     ! Fixed typo in ADSMGGETOPENTABLES2().
--
Brgds,
Viktor

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Mon May 26 07:55:48 2008
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Mon May 26 07:56:00 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour gpf
In-Reply-To: <006801c8bef5$1743e690$45cbb3b0$@com>
References: <006801c8bef5$1743e690$45cbb3b0$@com>
Message-ID: <20080526115548.GA8139@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>

On Sun, 25 May 2008, bhays wrote:

Hi Brian and others,

First sorry for the delay. I was absent for nearly a week and I
couldn't answer for the messages.
I'll try to answer for this messages in next days but I'm
really busy now - in two weeks I plan to make vacation break
and I have to finish all my business projects to this time
so I will not have too much time for Harbour.

> I didn?t report the problem correctly.
> To clarify, the test I sent gpfs when using Harbour ONLY if done as a
> Fivewin
> build.  The cmd-mode pure Harbour test works OK.
> There are in fact two problems then: That one, even with Harbour, and
> the second one which I found is due to changes Miguel did to the 
> xHarbour RDD area struct, adding a property to manage 
> USHORT uiFieldHidden   in the middle of the struct, plus two more to
> handle NULL fields. 
> Przemek, can you tell me if there?s any intention for Harbour to use
> the same approach for null fields?  I?m hoping to keep rddads share-able
> between the two projects, and thought we were keeping our RDD
> compatible as well.  

The code to support NULL fields in xHarbour is not finished and
still not functional so I do not want to take it as is. Farther
this extenssion is for keeping some low level RDD data in core
AREA structure from which all other RDDs inherits. This is IMHO
wrong. I can understand that we are moving some extensions to
core code for easier RDD integration. F.e. if we want to have
COPY TO / APPEND FROM working between RDDs then some informations
like field types have to be kept in core AREA structure because
different RDDs have to understand it. But moving system/hidden
columns which are used to store local to given RDD data does
not give anything valuable and creates things more complicated
because it's necessary to update other RDDs to play work with
some unusable in different architecture extenssions. In this
case information about hidden VFP columns should be moved to
DBFAREA structure. Just like now we have table with field offsets
which is local to DBFAREA only and we never tried to make it
global AREA member.
There is also difference in parameters two RDD node methods:
dbDrop() and dbExists(). In xHarbour they have additional
ulConnection parameter which is missing in Harbour and should
be added. I've made this modification long time ago but I've
never committed it waiting for 1.0. Anyhow it's such minor
extension then it can be added even now if it will help you
in synchronization process.
The last thing is the method how we are defining upper level
AREA structures.
We used to copy all members from SUPER RDD and then we are
adding new local to RDD members. It makes code harder to
updated and less readable. It will be much easier and cleaner
to declare new AREA structure adding as first member supper
AREA, f.e.:

typedef struct _ADSAREA_
{
   AREA     area;

   /*
    *  ADS's additions to the workarea structure
    *
    *  Warning: The above section MUST match WORKAREA exactly!  Any
    *  additions to the structure MUST be added below, as in this
    *  example.
    */

   LPDBRELINFO lpdbPendingRel;   /* Pointer to parent rel struct */

   char *   szDataFileName;      /* Name of data file */
   [...]
   ADSHANDLE hStatement;

} ADSAREA, * ADSAREAP;

With such definition you do not have to update each RDD when
sth will be change in core AREA structure and the RDD code
is more readable because you immediatelly see which parts
belongs to SUPER RDD and which ones are your own local
extensions, f.e.:

static ERRCODE adsBof( ADSAREAP pArea, BOOL * pBof )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("adsBof(%p, %p)", pArea, pBof));

   /* resolve any pending relations */
   if( pArea->lpdbPendingRel )
      SELF_FORCEREL( &pArea->area );

   *pBof = pArea->area.fBof;

   return SUCCESS;
}


In fact it will be good to update all core RDDs to respect it
but I do not have time to make it now.

> If we diverge at this point, I guess I can use #ifdef XHARBOUR to keep
> things shared, assuming you guys would want me to do that.

With above declaration you do not have to use any #ifdef ...

best regards,
Przemek
From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Mon May 26 07:58:30 2008
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)

best regards,

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Mon May 26 08:12:37 2008
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Mon May 26 08:12:41 2008
Subject: [Harbour] PCOUNT() compatibility
In-Reply-To: <483A8F80.6090209@dbtopas.lt>
References: <483A8F80.6090209@dbtopas.lt>
Message-ID: <20080526121237.GC8139@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>

On Mon, 26 May 2008, Mindaugas Kavaliauskas wrote:

Hi Mindaugas,

> Hello,
> PROC main()
>   aaa( 1 )
>   aaa( 1, 2 )
> RETURN
> PROC aaa( x )
>   ? PCOUNT()
> RETURN
> Clipper, xHarbour:
>          1
>          2
> Harbour:
>          1
>          1

Yes, I know about this behavior. It can be quite easy fixed
but I do not know if I want to make it ;-)
Please remeber we are removing additional items from HVM stack.
I can easy change value returned by PCOUNT() to be Clipper
compatible but it does not mean that it will change number
of parameters returned by hb_aParams() or allow to access
unused parameters in any other way (f.e. hb_pValue())
If you think that it should be changed them modification
in PCOUNT() is trivial but I do not want to touch hb_aPramas()
and hb_pValue(), just check what happens in xHarbour with
this code:

   #include "hbcompat.ch"
   PROC main()
     aaa( 1, 2, 3 )
   RETURN
   PROC aaa( x )
      LOCAL a := "a", b := "b"
     ? PVALUE( 1 ), PVALUE( 2 ), PVALUE( 3 )
   RETURN

best regards,
Przemek

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Mon May 26 08:18:07 2008
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Mon May 26 08:18:12 2008
Subject: [Harbour] BCC55 compile errors when HB_PCRE_REGEX defined
In-Reply-To: <9BB4C804-36C8-4E8D-AF6D-E4DBFC90BFAB@syenar.hu>
References: <9BB4C804-36C8-4E8D-AF6D-E4DBFC90BFAB@syenar.hu>
Message-ID: <20080526121807.GE8139@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>

On Wed, 21 May 2008, Szak?ts Viktor wrote:

Hi Viktor,

> Error E2340 source\rtl\hbregex.c 111: Type mismatch in parameter 6  
> (wanted 'int *', got 'int') in function hb_regexec
> Error E2340 source\rtl\hbregex.c 111: Type mismatch in parameter 7  
> (wanted 'int', got 'int *') in function hb_regexec
> Error E2227 source\rtl\hbregex.c 111: Extra parameter in call to  
> pcre_exec in function hb_regexec
> Error E2451 source\rtl\hbregex.c 548: Undefined symbol  
> 'pcre_stack_malloc' in function _hb_regex_init_
> Error E2451 source\rtl\hbregex.c 549: Undefined symbol  
> 'pcre_stack_free' in function _hb_regex_init_
> (tested with PCRE version currently in repo)

You mixed PCRE header files from Borland (it has some very old
PCRE implementation used for POSIX regex emulation) with code
for current PCRE version. If you want to use the BCC PCRE version
then you need to set HB_PCRE_REGEX_BCC macro (see hbregex.h)

best regards,
Przemek

From dbtopas at dbtopas.lt  Mon May 26 08:48:49 2008
From: dbtopas at dbtopas.lt (Mindaugas Kavaliauskas)
Date: Mon May 26 08:48:49 2008
Subject: [Harbour] PCOUNT() compatibility
In-Reply-To: <20080526121237.GC8139@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>
References: <483A8F80.6090209@dbtopas.lt>
	<20080526121237.GC8139@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>
Message-ID: <483AB1B1.7030105@dbtopas.lt>

Przemyslaw Czerpak wrote:
>> Hello,
>> PROC main()
>>   aaa( 1 )
>>   aaa( 1, 2 )
>> RETURN
>> PROC aaa( x )
>>   ? PCOUNT()
>> RETURN
>> Clipper, xHarbour:
>>          1
>>          2
>> Harbour:
>>          1
>>          1
> 
> Yes, I know about this behavior. It can be quite easy fixed
> but I do not know if I want to make it ;-)
> Please remeber we are removing additional items from HVM stack.
> I can easy change value returned by PCOUNT() to be Clipper
> compatible but it does not mean that it will change number
> of parameters returned by hb_aParams() or allow to access
> unused parameters in any other way (f.e. hb_pValue())
> If you think that it should be changed them modification
> in PCOUNT() is trivial but I do not want to touch hb_aPramas()
> and hb_pValue()

Hi,


yes, I understand these aspects of implementation, but I wanted to post 
sample code to show the problem and make discussion/solution public.

Actually, this property of Clipper's PCOUNT() was used in a real life 
code by my friend. He found his code producing a buggy results after 
moving from xHarbour to Harbour.

My opinion: I also thing we should not touch HB_AParams(), hb_PValue(). 
So, after fixing PCOUNT() to be Clipper compatible, the correct 
parameter evaluation loop would be:

   FOR nI := 1 TO LEN(HB_AParams())
     ? HB_PValue()
   NEXT

Of cause, it not nice solution, so I suggest to implement HB_PCount() 
for this purpose:

   FOR nI := 1 TO HB_PCount()
     ? HB_PValue()
   NEXT

HB_PCount(), HB_PValue() seems to be a well named function pair of true 
Harbour extensions. It's even more clear than HB_PValue() / PCOUNT(). 
The difference of HB_PCount() / PCOUNT() is easy to document. Clipper 
compatibility will be kept.


Best regards,
Mindaugas

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Mon May 26 09:02:27 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-2?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Mon May 26 09:03:42 2008
Subject: [Harbour] PCOUNT() compatibility
In-Reply-To: <483AB1B1.7030105@dbtopas.lt>
References: <483A8F80.6090209@dbtopas.lt>
	<20080526121237.GC8139@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>
	<483AB1B1.7030105@dbtopas.lt>
Message-ID: <950E6CC3-0107-4AEF-93F8-C29658008229@syenar.hu>

Hi folks,

The only thing I don't understand is why changing
HB_APARAMS(), HB_PVALUE() is not an option? To me
this would seem like a closer solution to the original
Clipper concept. If PCOUNT() would return extra params,
why couldn't the above two actually extract them?

If this is not possible I agree with adding HB_PCOUNT()
and fixing PCOUNT(). But IMO this will add some considerable
confusion for users (the difference will be difficult
to grasp for most ppl, but the question will always be
there, and at the end they will be using them randomly).

Brgds,
Viktor

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Mon May 26 10:25:46 2008
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Mon May 26 10:25:52 2008
Subject: [Harbour] PCOUNT() compatibility
In-Reply-To: <483AB1B1.7030105@dbtopas.lt>
References: <483A8F80.6090209@dbtopas.lt>
	<20080526121237.GC8139@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>
	<483AB1B1.7030105@dbtopas.lt>
Message-ID: <20080526142546.GA9051@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>

On Mon, 26 May 2008, Mindaugas Kavaliauskas wrote:
> yes, I understand these aspects of implementation, but I wanted to post 
> sample code to show the problem and make discussion/solution public.
> Actually, this property of Clipper's PCOUNT() was used in a real life 
> code by my friend. He found his code producing a buggy results after 
> moving from xHarbour to Harbour.

This is real argument. Someone may use PCOUNT() as additional method
of passing information to function. Not clear and well portable but
I believe that such code exists.
If you want to change it then you can simply use item.asSymbol.paramdeclcnt
instead of item.asSymbol.paramcnt in PCOUNT() function. If you want to
define the same behavior also for functions with variable number o
parameters then you should return maximum from both values.

> My opinion: I also thing we should not touch HB_AParams(), hb_PValue(). 
> So, after fixing PCOUNT() to be Clipper compatible, the correct 
> parameter evaluation loop would be:
>   FOR nI := 1 TO LEN(HB_AParams())
>     ? HB_PValue()
>   NEXT
> Of cause, it not nice solution, so I suggest to implement HB_PCount() 
> for this purpose:
>   FOR nI := 1 TO HB_PCount()
>     ? HB_PValue()
>   NEXT
> HB_PCount(), HB_PValue() seems to be a well named function pair of true 
> Harbour extensions. It's even more clear than HB_PValue() / PCOUNT(). 
> The difference of HB_PCount() / PCOUNT() is easy to document. Clipper 
> compatibility will be kept.

Yes and I like it. Anyhow we can also make sth else.
We have support for functions/procedures with variable number
of parameters, f.e.:
   func f( p1, p2, ... )
The mechanism created by Ryszard and used by Harbour for their
implementation resolves the problem with fixed parameter indexs and
LOCALs' positions which have to be calculated by compiler during
compilation. It means that we do not have to remove additional
parameters from HVM stack but internally we can use all functions
like functions with variable number of parameters. It's enough to
properly update item.asSymbol.paramdeclcnt and item.asSymbol.paramcnt.
If we make it then PCOUNT() will return exact number of parameters
passed by user and this parameters will be accessible by hb_pValue()/
hb_aParams() and similar functions.
The question is if we want to resolve it in such way or not.
BTW using this mechanism in all places we can simplify also other things
in compiler and HVM, f.e. we can eliminate updating local variables'
indexes after PARAMETERS command or separated [V]FRAME PCODEs and use
one for all cases.

best regards,
Przemek
From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Mon May 26 10:40:32 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-2?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)

Subject: [Harbour] PCOUNT() compatibility
In-Reply-To: <20080526142546.GA9051@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>

>> s and I like it. Anyhow we can also make sth else.
> We have support for functions/procedures with variable number
> of parameters, f.e.:
>   func f( p1, p2, ... )
> The mechanism created by Ryszard and used by Harbour for their

> If we make it then PCOUNT() will return exact number of parameters

> The question is if we want to resolve it in such way or not.
> BTW using this mechanism in all places we can simplify also other  
> things
> in compiler and HVM, f.e. we can eliminate updating local variables'

> one for all cases.

I update my vote for this solution.

[

That is, if I understood correctly:
- PCOUNT() would return the number of params passed, C5.x compatible.
- Len( hb_AParams() ) == PCOUNT()
- hb_PValue( n ) -> returns values for all n <= PCOUNT()

]

Brgds,
Viktor

From bedipritpal at hotmail.com  Mon May 26 12:51:48 2008
From: bedipritpal at hotmail.com (Pritpal Bedi)
Date: Mon May 26 12:51:51 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Performance - Class Variable vs Constant
Message-ID: <17475361.post@talk.nabble.com>


Hello 

I plan to introduce a class as:

CLASS WinDefines
   ACCESS ws_normal     INLINE 0
   ACCESS ws_hide        INLINE 1
   ACCESS wm_setfocus INLINE 0
   ACCESS ....
   
   METHOD New()
ENDCLASS

METHOD New() CLASS WinDefines()
RETURN Self

Then in program code:

Local wd := WinDefines():New()
   ...
   ShowWindow( wd:ws_hide )


The idea is to replace include files ( for application code ) with sometimes
is really a pain to find where a constant is buried.

It works fine. But my question is how big is the performance overhead if
this protocol is adopted in an application. 

Pros : It simplifies the development process, has room for adding future
inculsions, etc.
Cons : Only performance ( I am not sure really )

Before I jump into the venture I need your opinions.

Regards
Pritpal Bedi

PS: Idea has struck from Hennes Zigler's posts in xBase++ NG.
-- 
View this message in context: http://www.nabble.com/Performance---Class-Variable-vs-Constant-tp17475361p17475361.html
Sent from the Harbour - Dev mailing list archive at Nabble.com.

From dbtopas at dbtopas.lt  Mon May 26 13:43:22 2008
From: dbtopas at dbtopas.lt (Mindaugas Kavaliauskas)
Date: Mon May 26 13:43:19 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Performance - Class Variable vs Constant
In-Reply-To: <17475361.post@talk.nabble.com>
References: <17475361.post@talk.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <483AF6BA.8080001@dbtopas.lt>

> It works fine. But my question is how big is the performance overhead if
> this protocol is adopted in an application. 
> 
> Pros : It simplifies the development process, has room for adding future
> inculsions, etc.
> Cons : Only performance ( I am not sure really )

Hi,


just an idea:

nTime := SECONDS()
FOR nI := 1 TO 1000000
   F1()
NEXT
nTime1 := SECONDS() - nTime

nTime := SECONDS()
FOR nI := 1 TO 1000000
   F1( 12345 )
NEXT
nTime2 := SECONDS() - nTime

nTime := SECONDS()
FOR nI := 1 TO 1000000
   F1( Windows:Hide )
NEXT
nTime3 := SECONDS() - nTime

? nTime2 - nTime1
? nTime3 - nTime1

PROC F1(x);  RETURN



Best regards,
Mindaugas
From niki at synel.co.il  Mon May 26 13:42:12 2008
From: niki at synel.co.il (Chen Kedem)
Date: Mon May 26 13:46:52 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Performance - Class Variable vs Constant
Message-ID: <1A07FEDC778C3E4AA417F089511F859C0215F398B3@Mail-yoq.SYNEL-COMPANY.LTD>

Pritpal Bedi wrote:
> The idea is to replace include files ( for application code )

This looks like the .NET way of doing things.

> which sometimes is really a pain to find where a constant is buried

But your users will have to locate your documents or worse,
your source code to use these class members. An include file can
just be loaded into the user editor or IDE.

You can probably get a rough idea of speed if you loop 1000 or 5000 times
once using a constant and once using your class member as a parameter to
a function.

  Chen.
From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Mon May 26 14:04:49 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Mon May 26 14:05:56 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Performance - Class Variable vs Constant
In-Reply-To: <17475361.post@talk.nabble.com>
References: <17475361.post@talk.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <76D488AB-EE7C-422C-BE99-9472B2AD6CCD@syenar.hu>

>
Hi Pritpal,

> I plan to introduce a class as:
>
> CLASS WinDefines
>   ACCESS ws_normal     INLINE 0
>   ACCESS ws_hide        INLINE 1
>   ACCESS wm_setfocus INLINE 0
>   ACCESS ....
>
>   METHOD New()
> ENDCLASS
>
> METHOD New() CLASS WinDefines()
> RETURN Self
>
> Then in program code:
>
> Local wd := WinDefines():New()
>   ...
>   ShowWindow( wd:ws_hide )

CLASSDATA ws_normal READONLY INIT 0
would give better performance and memory usage.

But compared to #define, both performs poorly.

> The idea is to replace include files ( for application code ) with  
> sometimes
> is really a pain to find where a constant is buried.
>
> It works fine. But my question is how big is the performance  
> overhead if
> this protocol is adopted in an application.
>
> Pros : It simplifies the development process, has room for adding  
> future
> inculsions, etc.
> Cons : Only performance ( I am not sure really )
>
> Before I jump into the venture I need your opinions.
>
> Regards
> Pritpal Bedi
>
> PS: Idea has struck from Hennes Zigler's posts in xBase++ NG.

It's better if the language gives native support for 'const' values
(like C#, Java), but in C/Clipper/Harbour it's so much slower, that IMO
it's not justified for most cases. You also miss any compile-time
optimizations this way.

Brgds,
Viktor

I think that i explain very bad.

I want to say that when we open an existing DBF with CDX index
if the index was created with VFP it can contains the function TTOS
for this reason you can't add HB_ prefix when it will be created.

because it will breaks the possibility to support in the future full DBF 
format.

Harbour needs this function to support some kind of indexes.

instead of HB_TTOS  ;) as you normally change for extended harbour 
functions.

I never talk about xharbour. Only for teh future of harbour.

Miguel Angel Marchuet

From bedipritpal at hotmail.com  Mon May 26 16:20:46 2008
From: bedipritpal at hotmail.com (Pritpal Bedi)
Date: Mon May 26 16:20:49 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Performance - Class Variable vs Constant
In-Reply-To: <483AF6BA.8080001@dbtopas.lt>
References: <17475361.post@talk.nabble.com> <483AF6BA.8080001@dbtopas.lt>
Message-ID: <17478587.post@talk.nabble.com>


Hello


Mindaugas Kavaliauskas wrote:
> 
> nTime := SECONDS()
> FOR nI := 1 TO 1000000
>    F1()
> NEXT
> nTime1 := SECONDS() - nTime
> 
> nTime := SECONDS()
> FOR nI := 1 TO 1000000
>    F1( 12345 )
> NEXT
> nTime2 := SECONDS() - nTime
> 
> nTime := SECONDS()
> FOR nI := 1 TO 1000000
>    F1( Windows:Hide )
> NEXT
> nTime3 := SECONDS() - nTime
> 
> ? nTime2 - nTime1
> ? nTime3 - nTime1
> 
> PROC F1(x);  RETURN
> 

Windows:Hide approach is almost 6 times slower. Horrible. So I suspend this
extension.

Regards
Pritpal Bedi

-- 
View this message in context: http://www.nabble.com/Performance---Class-Variable-vs-Constant-tp17475361p17478587.html
Sent from the Harbour - Dev mailing list archive at Nabble.com.

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Mon May 26 19:11:21 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Mon May 26 19:12:32 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Unrecoverable error 9022: Memory buffer overflow
In-Reply-To: <17457392.post@talk.nabble.com>
References: <17457392.post@talk.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <DCFB0BE6-8D3D-4C63-A68C-78D0AE0732C5@syenar.hu>

> Borland C++ 5.5.1 for Win32 Copyright (c) 1993, 2000 Borland
> gdtest.c:
> Turbo Incremental Link 5.00 Copyright (c) 1997, 2000 Borland
> Error: Unresolved external '_gdImageDestroy' referenced from
> E:\HARBOUR\LIB\HBGD.LIB|gdwrp
> Error: Unresolved external '_gdImageCreateFromJpegPtr' referenced from
> E:\HARBOUR\LIB\HBGD.LIB|gdwrp

The problem is that bgd.dll is compiled using MSVC with stdcall,
so name mangling is underscore + func name + @ + params size
in bytes. Unfortunately BCC is not able to create the same kind
of name decoration however I tried. (I just can hope the BCC stdcall
call convention is the same as MSVCs.)

As a next step I generated a .def file from the .dll (using Borland
impdef), edited the .def file by prepending an underscore to the
function names (in the first column), then created a .lib file out of
the .def (using Borland implib). The resulting .lib links okay, and
test apps finally run.

Now gdtest.exe would print the lib version correctly, then runs
into a series of GPFs and exits without any more results.

Reading the FAQ on libgd.org, there are some serious problems
listed when using the .dll from anything compiled with BCC, with
some proposed workarounds.

I've tried all the above using an alternative win32 build (same
version), with exact same results.

I've also tried to compile gd lib from source, but that would need
a few days under Win32+BCC, considering there are 4 other lib
dependencies, and BCC is not supported out of the box.

Is there anybody successfully using the BCC version of hbgd?

[ BTW the whole thing works okay with MSVS 2005. I'll post one
correction to bin\bld.bat to fix building tests. ]

Brgds,
Viktor

From eghorbino at yahoo.com  Mon May 26 20:29:46 2008
From: eghorbino at yahoo.com (Edmer)
Date: Mon May 26 20:29:50 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Some problems with memoedit()
Message-ID: <17481052.post@talk.nabble.com>


Hi Gurus,

Below is a small test prg for memoedit. The issues that I encountered are
the following:

1. In the first memoedit, If you scroll further to the right it will create
blank columns when it scrolls and displays only a single column of
characters in the memoedit's rightmost column.

2. In the second memoedit, The initial display is word-wrapped even though
the line length I specified is greater than right-left and when you scroll
further to the right you will experience the same I mentioned in issue #1.

*---- Start here -----

PROCEDURE main
  Local t1
  set scoreboard off
  set exact on
  set softseek off
  set deleted off
  set date british
  set epoch to 1920
  set talk off

  t1 := replicate("The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog near the bank
of the river." + chr(13) + chr(10), 10)

  cls
  memoedit(t1,5,3,10,50,,,80)

  cls
  memoedit(t1,5,3,10,50,,,70)

RETURN

*----- Ends here ----------


Regards,
Ed

-- 
View this message in context: http://www.nabble.com/Some-problems-with-memoedit%28%29-tp17481052p17481052.html
Sent from the Harbour - Dev mailing list archive at Nabble.com.

From eghorbino at yahoo.com  Tue May 27 00:44:16 2008

Date: Tue May 27 00:44:19 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Issue #1 about GET command
Message-ID: <17483008.post@talk.nabble.com>


Hi Gurus,

Below is my test prg re GET. If I type in 1231234123456, The 456 at the end
of each GET is trimmed off. 

*--- Start here ---

PROCEDURE MAIN
  local getlist := {}
  local c1 := space(10)
  local c2 := space(10)
  local c3 := space(10)
  clear screen
  @ 1,1 get c1 pict "@R   999 9999 999999"
  @ 3,1 get c2 pict "@R  999  9999 999999"
  @ 5,1 get c3 pict "@R  999 9999  999999"
  read
  @ 8,1 say c1
  @ 9,1 say c2
  @ 10,1 say c3
RETURN

*--- Ends here ---

Regards,
Ed

From niki at synel.co.il  Tue May 27 01:27:42 2008
From: niki at synel.co.il (Chen Kedem)
Date: Tue May 27 01:32:23 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Issue #1 about GET command
Message-ID: <1A07FEDC778C3E4AA417F089511F859C0215F398B5@Mail-yoq.SYNEL-COMPANY.LTD>

Edmer wrote:
> If I type in 1231234123456, The 456 at the end of each GET is trimmed off.

>  local c1 := space(10)
>  local c2 := space(10)
>  local c3 := space(10)

Your data is 13 digits long, while your get buffer is only 10. So the last 3 are trimmed.
I can confirm that Clipper 5.2 assign the whole number to c1, c2 and c3 without trimming.

  Chen.
From eghorbino at yahoo.com  Tue May 27 01:38:39 2008
From: eghorbino at yahoo.com (Edmer)
Date: Tue May 27 01:38:41 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Issue #3 about GET command
Message-ID: <17483390.post@talk.nabble.com>


In the following test prg, If I typed 12345678.12345 in the GET the it will
display 12345678.12345 in the next line where the GET and SAY displays are
aligned. But if I didn't typed any data and just press <enter> only then it
will display _____12345.7689. The SAY display is not aligned with the GET
display by 2 spaces in the left. Please advice.

*--- Start here ---
PROCEDURE MAIN
  local getlist := {}
  local c1 := 12345.7689
  clear screen
  @ 1,1 get c1 pict "99999999.99999"
  read
  @ 3,1 say c1
RETURN

From mhsabado at gmail.com  Tue May 27 04:04:33 2008
From: mhsabado at gmail.com (Mario H. Sabado)
Date: Tue May 27 04:04:38 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Issue #3 about GET command
Message-ID: <f81ad3e40805270104x37f4a760ycf196c091dd08b2@mail.gmail.com>

Message: 10

Subject: [Harbour] Issue #3 about GET command
To: harbour@harbour-project.org
Message-ID: <17483390.post@talk.nabble.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


In the following test prg, If I typed 12345678.12345 in the GET the it will
display 12345678.12345 in the next line where the GET and SAY displays are
aligned. But if I didn't typed any data and just press <enter> only then it
will display _____12345.7689. The SAY display is not aligned with the GET
display by 2 spaces in the left. Please advice.

*--- Start here ---
PROCEDURE MAIN
 local getlist := {}
 local c1 := 12345.7689
 clear screen
 @ 1,1 get c1 pict "99999999.99999"
 read
 @ 3,1 say c1
RETURN
*---

Regards,
Ed
--------------

The same problem encountered when building the DBU utility with (x)Harbour.
When you open a table together with an existing index and try to rebuild the
index by pressing F3, 2 chars from left are truncated.

Regards,
Mario

-----Original Message-----
From: harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org
[mailto:harbour-bounces@harbour-project.org] On Behalf Of Randy Portnoff
Sent: Tuesday, August 07, 2007 5:32 PM
To: Harbour Project Main Developer List.; Harbour Project Main Developer
List.
Subject: Re: [Harbour] Viewer <-> XML <-> Application (was multi UI)

Hi all,

I am not sure if this helps you, but we are currently porting our
Windows app to Ajax - We intend on re-routing all the Windows API code
with calls to an Ajax Web client. We are developing an XML schema to
describe the user events and responses from the server. 
There will be one instance of the Win32 EXE running on one or more
servers (ie. server farms) for each web client instance. See the
attached diagram as an example of how we are implementing this. This
framework allows us to offer both a Windows and web client using the
same source code base.

Regards,
Randy.


From dbtopas at dbtopas.lt  Tue May 27 07:49:40 2008
From: dbtopas at dbtopas.lt (Mindaugas Kavaliauskas)
Date: Tue May 27 07:49:37 2008
Subject: [Harbour] PCOUNT() compatibility
In-Reply-To: <20080526142546.GA9051@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>
References: <483A8F80.6090209@dbtopas.lt>	<20080526121237.GC8139@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>	<483AB1B1.7030105@dbtopas.lt>
	<20080526142546.GA9051@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>
Message-ID: <483BF554.6090406@dbtopas.lt>

Hi,


Przemyslaw Czerpak wrote:
> Yes and I like it. Anyhow we can also make sth else.
> We have support for functions/procedures with variable number
> of parameters, f.e.:
>    func f( p1, p2, ... )
> The mechanism created by Ryszard and used by Harbour for their
> implementation resolves the problem with fixed parameter indexs and
> LOCALs' positions which have to be calculated by compiler during
> compilation. It means that we do not have to remove additional
> parameters from HVM stack but internally we can use all functions
> like functions with variable number of parameters. It's enough to
> properly update item.asSymbol.paramdeclcnt and item.asSymbol.paramcnt.
> If we make it then PCOUNT() will return exact number of parameters
> passed by user and this parameters will be accessible by hb_pValue()/
> hb_aParams() and similar functions.
> The question is if we want to resolve it in such way or not.
> BTW using this mechanism in all places we can simplify also other things
> in compiler and HVM, f.e. we can eliminate updating local variables'
> indexes after PARAMETERS command or separated [V]FRAME PCODEs and use
> one for all cases.


I've spend some time looking to the internals of .paramcnt, 
.paramdeclcnt. This seems to be a nice solution.

Perhaps the only "against" argument is more philosophical: do function 
has to support undeclared parameters? If all functions are variable 
number of parameters, is it allowed to use?:
   FUNC f1(a)
   LOCAL aRestOfParams := {...}
But we can block (if we decide to do this) usage of undeclared "..." at 
compiler level. Parameters accessing via HB_aParams()/HB_PValue() will 
be always possible.

I do not see any performance penalty. It will influence the order of 
destructors execution a little. Now extra params are itemClear'ed on 
hb_vmFrame() opcode. After the change it will be itemClear'ed on 
hb_stackOldFrame() (function exit). But I see no problem here.

I think you, Przemyslaw, see more "for" and "against". I trust your 
final decision.


Best regards,
Mindaugas

From druzus at acn.waw.pl  Tue May 27 11:43:01 2008
From: druzus at acn.waw.pl (Przemyslaw Czerpak)
Date: Tue May 27 11:43:06 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Habour will support 64 bit with windows?
In-Reply-To: <AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC7C@SRV02.deltain.net>
References: <AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC7B@SRV02.deltain.net>
	<20080527142912.GA15580@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>
	<AFB948164110ED43B5EB849E8DEEF03815EC7C@SRV02.deltain.net>
Message-ID: <20080527154301.GA19305@34-mo7-2.acn.waw.pl>

On Tue, 27 May 2008, Massimo Belgrano wrote:
> Wich c compiler?

I tested only MSVC64 but probably most of other C compilers
can be adopted very easy - when I was working on it only
MSVC64 were available. I've never tested MinGW64 so far
but if it reach usable state then it should work too.
In 64bit builds the most important were modifications in core
code which exists for very long time and are quite well tested
on different OSes and CPUs. I created 1-st 64 unix builds over 4
years ago. AFAIR later for WIN64 it was only one bigger modification
(support for 32bit LONG in 64bit address space) and some minor
cleanups.

best regards,
Przemek

Szak?ts Viktor wrote:
> 
> 
> The problem is that bgd.dll is compiled using MSVC with stdcall,
> so name mangling is underscore + func name + @ + params size
> in bytes. Unfortunately BCC is not able to create the same kind
> of name decoration however I tried. (I just can hope the BCC stdcall
> call convention is the same as MSVCs.)
> 
> As a next step I generated a .def file from the .dll (using Borland
> impdef), edited the .def file by prepending an underscore to the
> function names (in the first column), then created a .lib file out of
> the .def (using Borland implib). The resulting .lib links okay, and
> test apps finally run.
> 
> Now gdtest.exe would print the lib version correctly, then runs
> into a series of GPFs and exits without any more results.
> 
> Reading the FAQ on libgd.org, there are some serious problems
> listed when using the .dll from anything compiled with BCC, with
> some proposed workarounds.
> 
> 

Viktor,  I not understand why it works in xHarbour+BCC.


Szak?ts Viktor wrote:
> 
> [ BTW the whole thing works okay with MSVS 2005. I'll post one 
> correction to bin\bld.bat to fix building tests. ]
> 

I have also tried to compile with MSVC 7.10 

I add in contrib\mtpl_vc.mak this lines

!ifndef HB_VISUALC_VER
HB_VISUALC_VER = 71
!endif

and replace in test\bld_vc.bat
set HB_USER_LIBS=hbgd.lib bgd.lib hbct.lib =>
set HB_USER_LIBS=%HB_LIB_INSTALL%\hbgd.lib %HB_LIB_INSTALL%\bgd.lib
%HB_LIB_INSTALL%\hbct.lib

works fine, but i got
LINK : warning LNK4098: defaultlib 'LIBCMT' conflicts with use of other
libs; use /NODEFAULTLIB:library

no LNK4033 warning :)


Regards,
Petr

From harbour.01 at syenar.hu  Tue May 27 16:20:20 2008
From: harbour.01 at syenar.hu (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?Szak=E1ts_Viktor?=)
Date: Tue May 27 16:28:06 2008
Subject: [Harbour] Issue #1 about GET command
In-Reply-To: <17483008.post@talk.nabble.com>
References: <17483008.post@talk.nabble.com>
Message-ID: <0748CB84-FFDA-4BCA-9F9D-D625152B8FD4@syenar.hu>

Hi Edmer,

Thanks, I'll add Issue #1 and Issue #2 to rto_get.prg
test suite.

With Issue #1 the problem seems to be in ::unTransform()
(or maybe in ::picture()). Issue #2 is probably in ::PutMask()
These methods are general suspect for bugs, since they weren't
yet inspected thoroughly.

To ease finding some of these locally, here's what these
key methods do:

::picture() is responsible to analyze the picture value
and to set a few internal vars (::?Pic*) accordingly.

::unTransform() is responsible to assemble the GET var
value given the edit buffer, the picture string and
picture related internal vars (::?Pic*).

::PutMask() is responsible to format the edit buffer
the way the get should be displayed on screen, given
the GET var value and picture information.

Possible fix for Issue #1 is to remove the PadR()
expression from line 569 of /source/rtl/tget.prg.

Possible fix for Issue #2 is to add a space to the
second string in line 1765 of /source/rtl/tget.prg.

Please test these, I didn't check if they cause any
regressions.

Brgds,
Viktor

On 2008.05.27., at 6:44, Edmer wrote:

>
> Hi Gurus,
>
> Below is my test prg re GET. If I type in 1231234123456, The 456 at  
> the end
> of each GET is trimmed off.
>
> *--- Start here ---
>
> PROCEDURE MAIN
>  local getlist := {}
>  local c1 := space(10)
>  local c2 := space(10)
>  local c3 := space(10)
>  clear screen
>  @ 1,1 get c1 pict "@R   999 9999 999999"
>  @ 3,1 get c2 pict "@R  999  9999 999999"
>  @ 5,1 get c3 pict "@R  999 9999  999999"
>  read
>  @ 8,1 say c1
>  @ 9,1 say c2
>  @ 10,1 say c3
> RETURN
>
> *--- Ends here ---
>
> Regards,
> Ed
>

On Thu, 22 May 2008, Guy Roussin wrote:

Hi,

> I notice that HB_CONTRIBLIBS in make_deb.sh is not taken into
> account by dpkg-buildpackage -b
> As a workaround i add this line before dpkg-buildpackage -b :
> export HB_CONTRIBLIBS

Not workaround but fix. The export is necessary. Thanks for the
info.

> So even if the package libpq-dev is there, libhbpgsql.a is not
> compiled.
> I also suggest to add those lines in make_deb.sh :
> if test_reqpkg libmysqlclient15-dev
> then
>      HB_CONTRIBLIBS="${HB_CONTRIBLIBS} hbmysql"
> fi

Thank you very much for suggestions.
I'll make the modifications but I do not use any DEB based
distribution and I cannot test them. If possible I'd like
to ask you to commit necessary fixes and cleanups.

I want to ask all users using Debian or Ubuntu to make tests
and required updates or to send information about found problems
to this list.

best regards,
Przemek
